The Shore Temple in Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu, India is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the oldest surviving stone temples in the country. Built in the 7th century, it is known for its architectural and sculptural excellence, and is considered a testament to the early Dravidian style of temple architecture. The temple is located on the shore of the Bay of Bengal and is dedicated to Lord Shiva.

The Shore Temple in Mahabalipuram, Tamil Nadu, India is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the oldest surviving stone temples in the country. Built in the 7th century, it is known for its architectural and sculptural excellence, and is considered a testament to the early Dravidian style of temple architecture. Shore Temple, Mahabalipuram :—

The Shore Temple is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in Mahabalipuram, a coastal town in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu. It was built during the reign of the Pallava dynasty in the 7th and 8th centuries AD and is considered to be one of the earliest examples of South Indian temple architecture. The temple consists of two main structures, both of which are dedicated to the Hindu gods Shiva and Vishnu, and are situated on the shores of the Bay of Bengal. The Shore Temple is known for its unique blend of architectural styles, with elements of Dravidian, Indo-Aryan, and Greco-Roman influence, and is considered a masterpiece of Pallava architecture. Despite the damage it has suffered from natural elements over the centuries, it remains a popular tourist destination and a symbol of India's rich cultural heritage.

What is the significance of the Shore Temple in Mahabalipuram?

SHORE TEMPLE:

The Shore Temple of Mahabalipuram in TN had been identified by several sailors and navigators right since the 7th century. The creation of this complex was initialized during the reign of King Narasimha Varma I who was called by the name Mahamalla, after whom the city was named Mamallapuram.

THE LOCAL FISHERMEN:

The local fishermen always knew about ruins under the water near Shore Temple, the scientific community became convinced about this in 2002 – 2004 when researchers found remnants of some structures near the temple.

THE TSUNAMI:

In December 2004 something more significant happened The catastrophic tsunami hit the coast. Before it, the sea receded for some 500 meters and to the surprised visitors opened a long, straight row of large rocks. Then the terrible waves came. After these waves appeared some more wonders of the past, a large sculpture of a lion, half-completed relief of an elephant and others. Waves removed the silt and opened a heritage which was hidden from our eyes for centuries.

THE DISCOVERY:

After the tsunami ASI & Indian Navy started more thorough research in the sea. They discovered remnants of numerous buildings, walls, platforms, broken pillars, and other details. Style of carving and also gave a hint that these structures, most likely, were built during the Pallava era. Sonography showed that there are clusters of rectangular structures – possible fundaments of houses – on the sea ground.

MY VISIT:

I recently visited the temple with my friends and I came across many such jaw droppings facts, which actually fascinated me to go back to the history of this archeological beauty.

In total there were found five interesting locations. Thus, some 700 m east from Shore Temple is a structure which sometimes, at low tide, appears above the water. Its base is at the depth of some 6 m. The structure is some 75 by 35 m large and consists of a single, massive platform with traces of several smaller buildings on it. Enormous, approximately 2x1x1.5 meters large blocks of granite were used.

The temple is one of the oldest surviving examples of South Indian architecture and is believed to have been built in the 7th or 8th century AD, during the reign of the Pallava dynasty.

The Shore Temple is a rock-cut Hindu temple located in the ancient port city of Mahabalipuram, on the Bay of Bengal coast in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu. The temple is one of the oldest surviving examples of South Indian architecture and is believed to have been built in the 7th or 8th century AD, during the reign of the Pallava dynasty.

The Shore Temple is considered to be a UNESCO World Heritage Site and is one of the most iconic landmarks of Mahabalipuram. The temple is situated on a rocky promontory that juts out into the Bay of Bengal, and its location close to the shore makes it a popular destination for tourists and visitors. The temple is known for its intricate carvings and sculptures, including depictions of Hindu gods and goddesses, as well as scenes from Hindu mythology.

The Shore Temple is a unique and remarkable example of ancient Indian architecture, and its beauty and historical significance have made it one of the most popular tourist destinations in India. Visitors to the temple can explore the intricate carvings, admire the stunning views of the Bay of Bengal, and learn about the rich cultural heritage of India.

What are the best shore temples in India?

I haven’t made a tour of shore temples throughout India, but I will definitely recommend the Bhagawati Amman Temple of Kanyakumari, Tamil Nadu, on the very southernmost point of India, at the confluence of the Bay of Bengal, the Arabian Sea, and the Indian Ocean. It’s a powerful temple and also a beautiful spot to view the sunrise and sunset over the ocean. I especially recommend visiting the temple very early in the morning, around 4am or so, for the first morning Suprabhatam rituals. You may need to arrange this with a priest the day before to make sure you will be let in.

What is the naming history of Mahabalipuram?

What is the naming history of Mahabalipuram?

It is a very interesting question to answer.

Even today, the name Mahabalipuram is the mainstream name of this place since historical times of 7th century AD, even though present Tamilnadu government chose to call it Mamallapuram. The road from Madras/Chennai Adayar via Sholinganallur to Mahabalipuram is still called as 'old Mahabalipuram Road '.

Then one must be wondering why it is being now a days being projected as or called as 'Mamallapuram'?

Is there any precedence for this name 'Mamallapuram', how it came into existence?.

Yes, there is a very solid precedence to this - it was originally 'MahaMallapuram wherein it was named after the title of the 'Greatest Pallava king Narasimha varma I' - who was given a title of 'Maha Malla' or Greatest/Exalted Wrestler' (Maha - Greatest/Exalted ; Malla - Wrestler (as in Malla Yodha). And over period of time it got to be known as 'Mamalla' in local slang.

Pallavas were originally from Pallavanadu or Palnadu region of Andhra (originally Pahlavas or Indo-Parthians from present day Malwa region (AkaraAvanti or Ujjain in present Madhya Pradesh) subjugated by Andhra Satavahana king Gautamiputra Satakarni-GPS and brought to Andhra Palnadu region). Pallavas started as feudators to Andhra Satavahana's but after the decline of Satavahana's around 230 AD), they become independent dynasty kings (~270 AD to 897 AD) in the late 3rd century and firmly established themselves in Mid 4th century after firmly defeating Chola kings and capturing Kanchipuram in present Tamilnadu and made it as their Capital till the end of this dynasty (as per Velurpalaiyam copper plate inscription). In fact, it would be interesting to know that in the Allahabad pillar inscriptional eulogy of Samudra Gupta, there was a mention of Pallava king Virakurcha - when Samudra Gupta briefly conquested along the east coastal corridor (along Odisha, Andhra coasts) upto Kanchipuram around 340 AD.

Pallavas from early years till mid of 6th century AD heavily patronized Sanskrit (official court language), Prakrit & Telugu (as they ruled southern parts of AP also) having several inscriptions and Prasasthis in Kanchipuram and Mahamallapuram in Sanskrit. Mahendra Varma I himself was the author of the Sanskrit play Mattavilasa Prahasana and another play called Bhagavadajjuka

Coin of the Pallavas of Coromandel, king Narasimhavarman I in Sanskrit (630-668 AD).Obv Lion left RevName of Narasimhavarman with solar and lunar symbols around.

Pallava kings used to have Telugu Birudu's or honorary titles as Malla's (Wrestler's) - Mahendravarma I as 'Satru Malla - a warrior who overthrows his enemies'. His son Narasimha Varma I has got a title of 'Maha Malla - Great/Exalted Warrior' after he killed Chalukya king Pulakesin II in the fiercest battle of Vatapi /Badami (It would be interesting to know Pulakeshi Ii himself a giant killer who defeated Harshavardhana of Thanesar). Maha Malla only got also known to be as 'Maha Bali' in Sanskrit meaning 'one with great strength or great Warrior '.

In fact the Mahabalipuram (now a UNESCO heritage site) had also got another name 'Maha Mallapuram' after Narasimha varma I, which got transformed into present day 'Mamallapuram'. His son Parameswaravarma I had a title of 'Eka Malla - the sole Warrior or Wrestler's.

Pallavas had many Sanskrit inscriptions at Kanchipuram and Mahabalipuram-MahaMallapuram from the times of Mahendravarman I and Narasimhavarman I. But in later times from 550 AD onwards they started heavily Patronizing Tamil and made great contributions to Grantha and Pallava script. Pallava - Chola fusion script after 850AD gave rise to modern Tamil script. Pallava itself a Sanskrit word meaning 'creeper branch' (famous pancha Pallavas flowering tree branches). During the time of Mahendra Varna I, the rock cut temples of Mahabalipuram works have started and finished and city got commissioned by his son Narasimha Varma I or Maha Malla. Mahabalipuram was also one of the main port city for Pallavas from where sea trade used to be carried out with far East Asian countries as far as till China. It was during Narasimhavarma I reign, in 640 AD, that the Chinese traveller Hiuen Tsang believed have visited Kanchipuram. Even one of Pallava kings son Bodhi Varma has supposedly visited China who got to be famously also known as Damo (Kungfu master) or Bodhi Dharman.

So, this was also the precedence for summit meeting of Modi - Jinping's trade talks in Mahabalipuram.

There were very many interesting facts, achievements and cultural contributions from Pallava dynasty kings who have richly contributed to the cultural legacy of present Tamilnadu.

The Sea Shore temple of Mahabalipuram inscription of Raja Simha Pallava (another title name Narasimha Varma II 700–728 AD) clearly mentions the Telugu/Sanskrit title 'MahaMalla' on the northern side of the inscription on the Platform B. The entire inscription is in Samskrta and written in Grantha script (a script developed by Pallava 's only for writing Sanskrit).

The entire inscription is published in “Epigraphia Indica Vol. XIX by Sri V.Rangacharya.

this original inscription may be available in Madras/Chennai archealogical Museum.

SEA SHORE TEMPLE INSCRIPTION OF RĀJASIṂHA PALLAVA

It clearly says

Yamarthyadrushto ShatrunaMalla MahaMallam |

TrinayanaBhaktham Mitram …Narendrasimha-nnamanthi Nrupah || (6)

The kings bow to him, who sees the means, the Wrestler to the Enemies and a Great Wrestler, devotee of Siva and the Lion among the Kings.

Another set of references from this book

Rabe, Michael Dan (1987). The Monolithic Temples of the Pallava Dynasty: A Chronology. University of Minnesota.

in this book of Mr. Michael Dan Rabe, published by University of Minnesota, happened to have captured many inscriptional references along with their translation have given many direct references that Narasimha Varma I was directly mentioned as 'MahaMalla Narasimha I' and not as ‘Mamallan’ - pg 199.

Another reference, more importantly even in Chalukya inscription from Gadwal (present Telangana - erstwhile Andhra Pradesh) they referred to Pallava's as 'the family of Mahamalla' in a revenge context as 'Maha Malla' Narasimha Varma I' has sacked the Chalukya capital Vatapi/Badami - page 221.

Thus the famous Seashore temple inscription of Mahabalipuram the book references by Mr. Michael Rabe clearly mentions the specific word 'MahaMalla' in Sanskrit/Telugu in direct reference to Narasimha Varma I and definitely not as 'Mamallan - which is a mere Tamil loan Corruption much later. In 1957, after Independence, Tamilnadu government changed the name Mahabalipuram to Mamallapuram, out of pressure from political Dravidian outfits, through a Government Order gazette notification claiming that Mamallapuram is the original name.

Conclusive summary:

So, Pallava dynasty kings have definitely used Sanskrit as royal inscriptional language since the inception (270 AD till late 7th century AD and they used their own Pallava Grantha script for writing Samskrta. And later they patronized Tamil language. There is a fusion language of 'Manipravalam' (fusion of Sanskrit-Tamil) and the same Grantha script was also used to write 'Manipravalam'. Moreover, modern Malayalam script has also Grantha script influence and it is a fact that Malayalam has also heavy influence of Samskrta.

So, that is how MahaMallaPuram as mentioned directly in Royal Pallava kings inscriptions (also popular as MahaBaliPuram) of ancient India now got to be known as Mamallapuram.

If one were in the desert with no water, and all one had was a bottle of whiskey, would drinking it make one die sooner or later?


Drinking the whiskey would make someone die sooner.

Any kind of alcohol inhibits (deactivates) antidiuretic hormone (ADH) which is also known as vasopressin.

Antidiuretic hormone is responsible for water re-absorption in urine production. When ADH is present, the water in urine is transferred back into blood stream. Thus, it protect us against excessive water loss during urine production.

Drinking the whiskey would make someone die sooner.

Any kind of alcohol inhibits (deactivates) antidiuretic hormone (ADH) which is also known as vasopressin.

Antidiuretic hormone is responsible for water re-absorption in urine production. When ADH is present, the water in urine is transferred back into blood stream. Thus, it protect us against excessive water loss during urine production.

When there is enough amount of alcohol in blood stream, it inhibits (deactivates) ADH. So, water transfer from urine to blood stream highly decreased. As a result, urine volume increases and water amount in blood is decreases. This will lead to dehydration and eventually death.

Do you believe in astrology, and why or why not?

I never used to believe in Astrology and would hate it when my parents would follow it. But as life is unpredictable, I ended up believing in it and became one of those. Below is my story:

I often come across this question from my friends in a very astonishing way, “How come you into Astrology?,” as I had mocked everyone who ever talked about astrology. However, today I can share my journey with everyone.

Back in 2013, I quit my job with Nomura to pursue my dreams but things didn’t go as planned and I struggled for a year and exhausted my savings. To make ends meet, I went back to Mumbai and did some odd jobs as I was not getting shortlisted for any technology job interviews, citing a gap of one year. After some networking, an old colleague referred me to BNP Paribas and I got the job at a pay cut.

After working there for a year, I got in touch with one of my school friends, who later went to IIT Delhi, and we both planned to start an IT services company. It was time to put down the papers yet again, and I typed the resignation letter with full enthusiasm (that time I didn’t have to look for email templates on Google) but I got very anxious before sending it, as the old struggling days started haunting me.

As I was staring dead at the resignation email, one of my colleagues came over and inquired, “Is everything okay? You look lost.” I showed her my resignation letter and told her how my negative thoughts are not letting me do what I wanted to.

She looked at me with empathy and said, “I can see your birth chart and tell you what to do as per Astrology. What are your birth details?” and she opened one very badly designed app on her phone to input my details. I was shocked and amused at the same time. I promised myself to hire good UI/UX designers to develop better apps than that).

“Seriously? Do you think I believe in all this? Padhe likhe hoke aap andh vishwas faila rahe ho!” I scolded her but I wished I could get some help.

She waited for me to complete and demanded, “Are you done? Now tell me your birth details. I don’t care if you believe or not but let me try to help.” I shared the details as I would rather not mess with a senior. But knowing her coding skills, I could totally judge that she would screw up in Astrology as well.

As she was analysing my chart, I waited curiously to know the outcome, the way I had waited for my 10th standard board results. There is something about Astrology, it doesn’t matter whether you believe in it or not, but it fascinates you like nothing else. However, as I didn’t trust her and would never have liked to take a biased decision based on Astrology, so I quickly sent the resignation letter and locked my screen. Meanwhile, she was done with her calculations and it was time for the results.

“You are Leo Ascendant and your Sun is exalted…” I interrupted her in between and asked, “I don’t understand all this. Tell me something about the past to make me believe you,” I was such a spoiler.

“Beta, jitna tu bhaagta hai na isse, aage jake utna jaada believe karega (Dear, as much as you are mocking this today, you will believe in it much more, in future),” She mocked me this time but after hearing that I was convinced she knew Astrology as good as Database designing, as I would never do that.

“You don’t choose Astrology, Astrology chooses you”

Then she told me many things about my past to make her point including the date of my accident in school days, which was shocking. And once she observed the change in my body language, she stopped telling about the past and came to the main question. She not only predicted the past correctly but was also such a nice observer of behaviour. Oh God! Why the hell was she a MySQL developer?

“Yes, you can quit your job as the next two years are very promising for an IT business as per the placement of Saturn and Rahu,” she smiled as she made the prediction. I am still not sure if that smile was for a positive prediction or for the virtual win over me.

“Just two years?,” I exclaimed with a sheepish laugh as I had to pretend that I was not interested.

Like every other story, this story was also filled with some twist and turns. After that, I served my notice period and came to Noida and started an IT services company named CodeYeti in April 2015. And that reminded me about the prediction, my ex-colleague had made about my partner’s exit. I called her after a gap of two years (Let’s just assume that I was busy and was not bad at keeping in touch) and told her about the prediction.

I could sense the happiness in her voice as her prediction came true but she showed concern as it was a loss for me. To my surprise, she knew everything about CodeYeti as she followed our social media channels and congratulated me for what we had achieved in such a short duration.

INTRODUCTION:

INTRODUCTION:

Panch Rathas are 5 monolithic temples built by the Pallavas in the early 7th century AD. Situated in Mahabalipuram, the Pancha Rathas display exquisite carvings carved out from a single large boulder.

They are named after the 5 Pandavas and their wife Draupadi. However, as the names might suggest, the temples are not related to the Pandavas of Mahabharata.

ARCHITECTURE:

The construction of the Rathas is believed to have been started by King Mahendravarman I of the Pallava dynasty. It was continued by his son Narasimhavarman I in the early 7th century AD.

Based on the ornamentation & sculptures however, it can be safely assumed that they were supposed to be temples dedicated to Lord Shiva, Vishnu, Indra, and Durga.

SOME UNSUNG FACTS:

Pancha Rathas belong to very rare examples where whole buildings with ornate exterior & interior are cut from the cliff.

Sadly, the Pancha Rathas were unfinished; records suggest that the death of the King Narasimhavarman must have stopped it.

Even the change in administration might be the reason for the incomplete architecture.

BEST TIME TO VISIT:

Best time to visit the Mahabalipuram Rathas, which is renowned for its architectural and creative brilliance, is from December to March. The entry ticket for Indian citizen is 10 rupees and for foreigners it's 250 rupees.

The Temple’s name is derived from the words kapalam (Head) and Eeshwarar an alias of shiva.

A striking feature of this ancient temple is its towering gopurams (towers) – typical of South Indian temples. The gopurams are richly-carved pyramid-like rectangular structures that serve as a gateway to temples in South India. Within the temple complex, you will also see a tank (another prominent feature of a South Indian temple complex) and inscriptions from the puranas dating back to the 13th century.Outside the temple, the street is lined with shops selling fresh flowers, incense and sweets to offer to the deity.

Which is older, the Kanchi Kailasanathar Temple or the Tanjavur Brihadeeswara Temple?

The Kanchi Kailasanathar temple was built by Rajasimha Pallava (Narasimhavaraman II) about 300 years before the big temple. However, it is built mostly of Sandstone, so it is eroding with time, whereas the Brihadeeswara temple was built of granite brought from where? we do not know! So, it has better withstood the vigors of time. However, the Pallavas were the true pioneers in the Dravidian style of building temples, starting with Simhavishnu, Mahendravarman, and Narasimhavarman, and finally, Rajasimha. So this helped the Cholas a lot.

Nevertheless, both temples are a great reminder of our proud and checkered heritage, plundered but mostly left untouched by the invaders from Arabia and Persia, probably because they were way in the South . Imagine a time when Kanchi was a great center of learning, philosophy, and learning: “Pushpeshu Jathi, Purusheshu Vishnu, Nareeshu Ramba, Nagareshu Kanchi” attributed to Kalidasa. It was the center of Buddhist, Jainist, Vashnaivist, and finally Shivaite philospohy and temples.

Thanjavur, being near the Holy Cauvery, has been a capital city of the Cholas intermittently for a long time. The “Kallanai” originally built by Karikala Cholan is nearby in Thiruchi district. The Cauvery is probably how the stones were transported to build the great temple. Hundreds of elephants, and thousands of people (some of them likely prisoners of wars with other states) were likely used in its construction. We do not think about the work and sacrifice of these people, animals, architects, and Silpis when we visit this temple, and say our prayers, but probably should!

If you have not already, I hope that you have the chance to visit both temples. Also visit the “Ucchi Pillayar Temple” in Thiruchi (known in ancient times as Urayur), the Little Temple in Gangai Konda Cholapuram, built by Rajendra Chola (he built it a little shorter than the big temple out of love and reverence to his father Rajaraja Chola), and of course the great Sri Rangam temple!

When was the Mahabalipuram Temple built?

(Image Source: Shore Temple - Wikipedia)

Mahabalipuram, also known as Mamallapuram, is a historic city and a UNESCO World Heritage site located in Tamil Nadu, India. Between the 3rd and 7th Century CE, the city became an important centre of literature, art, and architecture under the patronage of Pallava dynasty.

The city was a thriving seaport on the shores of Bay of Bengal and was a centre of trade relations with the Romans even before it was included into the territory of the Pallava Empire.

The early history of the city is completely shrouded in mystery. It is only during the reign of Mahendravarman I who ruled from 600 CE – 630 CE, Mahabalipuram started to flourish as a centre of culture and art. The period of artistic excellence was further continued by his son Narasimhavarman I who ruled from 630 CE – 680 CE and also by the subsequent Pallava kings.

The Shore Temple of Mahabalipuram is located on the beach. According to folklore, it is one of the surviving legendary Seven Pagodas. It was built during the reign of Narasimhavarman II between 700 and 728 CE.

Who built the Sea Shore Temple in Mahabalipuram?

Who built the seven Pagodas (Sea Shore Temple) ? MAMALLAPURAM was variously called Mallai, Kadal Mallai and Mamallai. Its breathtaking monuments were built by the Pallava kings, who ruled from the 3rd century A.D. to the 8th century A.D. from their capital at Kanchipuram. The monuments at Mamallapuram were built by Narasimhavarman I, Paramesvarman and Narasimhavarman II, who ruled during the 7th and 8th centuries. The monuments can be categorised thus: the rock-cut cave temples; the monolithic free-standing rathas; open air-bas-relief; and the structural temples. It should be noted here that Pallava Kings were called with their title, {for example “Narasimha Verma Pallavan”, Mahendra Verma Pallavan, etc.]

Origin of its name: The Shore Temple of Mahabalipuram in the state of Tamil Nadu had been identified by several sailors and navigators right since the 7th century. It was named as the Shore temple by foreigners in order to mark the mainland. The creation of this complex was initialised during the reign of King Narasimha Varma I who was called by the name Mahamalla, after whom the city was named as Mahamallaouram and gradually Mahabalipuram.

In retrospect:"Mamallapuram, under its European name of Seven Pagodas, enters the records of Fort St. George, Madras, in 1708. An entry mentions a letter sent to the `Super Gargoe or Commander of the English Ship riding near the Seven Pagodas." Another entry, dated November 17, 1721, records a letter from the "Chief of the Flemings at Covelong, advising that an English ship was stranded at Mauvalipuram... " A Frenchman called Sonnerat, who travelled in the East Indies and China "by order" of Louis XIV between 1774 and 1781, visited Mamallapuram. He talks about "the temple named the Seven Pagodas, which one sees between Sadras and Pondicherry".

In 1778, William Chambers wrote an article on the monuments at Mamallapuram in the first volume of Asiatic Researches published from Calcutta (now Kolkata). He visited the site in 1772 and 1776. "He raises two questions, the origin and significance of the European name of Seven Pagodas and the existence of a city or at least of buildings submerged in the sea off Mamallapuram."

Legend associated: An ancient Hindu legend explains the pagodas' origin. Prince Hiranyakasipu refused to worship the god Vishnu. The prince's son, Prahlada, loved Vishnu greatly and criticized his father's lack of faith. Hiranyakasipu banished Prahlada but then relented and allowed him to come home. Father and son quickly began to argue about Vishnu's nature. When Prahlada stated that Vishnu was present everywhere, including in the walls of their home, his father kicked a pillar. Vishnu emerged from the pillar in the form of a man with a lion's head, and killed Hiranyakasipu. Prahlada eventually became king, and had a grandson named Bali. Bali founded Mahabalipuram on this site.

During Tsunami in 2004, when the waves that engulfed the Mamallapuram beach receded, they washed away from the beach a vast quantity of sand into the sea, the ASI has made valuable discoveries of dressed rocks in a square area whioch were the remains of a massive temple, which when it existed, would have rivaled the Shore Temple in size and grandeur. The collapsed ‘temple had been built entirely of granite blocks. The parts of the collapsed temple that have surfaced include a square Garbha Griha (sanctum sanctorum), a wide courtyard, a thick prakara or wall made of granite boulders, an elegant terracotta ring well, a kalasha; a carved capstone; a stupika and a sitting lion sculpted out of sandstone. There is also a sandstone sculpture depicting perhaps the Pallava King Narasimhavarman I.

The phrase "Seven Pagodas" refers to a belief that has circulated in India, Europe, and other parts of the world for over eleven centuries. The group of Monuments at Mahabalipuram, including the Shore Temple built in the 7th century under the reign of Narasimhavarman II, stand at the shore of the Bay of Bengal. According to a myth that has circulated around India and Europe for over 11 centuries, seven temples once stood along Mahabalipuram's shore. Local legend suggests that the god Indra became jealous of this earthly city and sank it during a great storm, leaving only the Shore Temple above sea level. The centre piece of these discoveries is a fragmented stone with inscription in Tamil, which reads: cika malla eti... ma. It provides evidence that the collapsed temple was built by the Pallava kings. However, there are conflicting reports on the existence of the seven Pagodas and the Tamizh inscriptions.

Anecdotal evidence can be truthful though, and in 2002 scientists decided to explore the area off the shore of Mahabalipuram, where many modern Tamil fishermen claimed to have glimpsed ruins at the bottom of the sea. This project was a joint effort between the National Institute of Oceanography (India) and the Scientific Exploration Society, U.K. ( NIO Scientist K.H. Vora). The two teams found the remains of walls beneath 5 to 8 meters of water and sediment, 500 to 700 meters off the coast. The layout suggested that they belonged to several temples. Archaeologists dated them to the Pallava era, roughly when Mahendravarman I and Narasimharavarman I ruled the region. NIO scientist K.H. Vora noted after the 2002 exploration that the underwater site probably contained additional structures and artifacts, and merited future exploration.

Who build the Mahabalipuram temples in Tamil Nadu?

The Mahabalipuram temples were built by various kings from the Later Pallava Dynasty that reigned over regions of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu with the capital city at Kanchipuram from early 6th century to late 9th century AD. Among the kings, the noteworthy contributions to Mahabalipuram were mainly from following emperors:

  • Mahendravarman I (590–630 AD),
  • Narasimhavarman I(630–668AD),
  • Paramaswaravarman (672–700AD) and
  • Narasimhavarman ll also called as Rajasimhan (700–728AD).

Mahabalipuram aka Mamallapuram was a thriving port already and the temples were just feathers to the cap of the commercial c

The Mahabalipuram temples were built by various kings from the Later Pallava Dynasty that reigned over regions of Andhra Pradesh and Tamil Nadu with the capital city at Kanchipuram from early 6th century to late 9th century AD. Among the kings, the noteworthy contributions to Mahabalipuram were mainly from following emperors:

  • Mahendravarman I (590–630 AD),
  • Narasimhavarman I(630–668AD),
  • Paramaswaravarman (672–700AD) and
  • Narasimhavarman ll also called as Rajasimhan (700–728AD).

Mahabalipuram aka Mamallapuram was a thriving port already and the temples were just feathers to the cap of the commercial city of the pallavas. The word “Mamallapuram” comes from the word “Mamallan” (GrandWrestler), Malyudham -(Wrestling) referring to the great Narasimhavarman l as he was a great wrestler of his time and the city is called so to commemorate his legacy. Wrestling was greatly encouraged and practiced by the kings as a part of their training, as well as a hobby. Narasimhavarman l showed exemplary skills in wrestling and was awarded the title “Mamallan”.

The Pallavas contributed a lot to the rich cultural-heritage of ancient India which I would be discussing in my upcoming blog.

How can I reach Mahabalipuram from Chennai?

It depends on from which locality in Chennai you are starting from. It appears that you might be a tourist. So, the localities are most likely Chennai Central or Egmore railway stations or Chennai Airport.

By Public transport:

From Chennai Central or Egmore:

First go to CMBT bus station (Take 15B run by MTC, available every 5 minutes). From CMBT, get a bus to Pondicherry via ECR (Frequency every 10 - 15 mins). That bus can take you to Mahabalipuram.

Alternatively take Bus A1 (from Central) or 23C (from Egmore) to reach Thiruvanmiyur. From Thiruvanmiyur, you get both MTC buses and mofussil buses to

It depends on from which locality in Chennai you are starting from. It appears that you might be a tourist. So, the localities are most likely Chennai Central or Egmore railway stations or Chennai Airport.

By Public transport:

From Chennai Central or Egmore:

First go to CMBT bus station (Take 15B run by MTC, available every 5 minutes). From CMBT, get a bus to Pondicherry via ECR (Frequency every 10 - 15 mins). That bus can take you to Mahabalipuram.

Alternatively take Bus A1 (from Central) or 23C (from Egmore) to reach Thiruvanmiyur. From Thiruvanmiyur, you get both MTC buses and mofussil buses to Mahabalipuram - just inquire the locals for the appropriate bus stop.

From airport:

The convenient way with just one change is to first get a bus to CMBT (70, 70A, 70V, 170). Then from CMBT, get a bus to Pondicherry via ECR (Frequency every 10 - 15 mins). That bus can take you to Mahabalipuram. But this route is going to take a lot of time. Shorter routes exist but you may have to change more buses.

Alternatively, you can get a Ola or Uber outstation. Not sure about the costs though!

What is the Annapoorna temple?

Annapurna Devi Mandir is one of the most famous Hindu temples in the holy city of Varanasi. This temple has great religious importance in Hinduism and is dedicated to the goddess Annapurna. Annapurna is the Hindu goddess for nourishment and is a form of the goddess Parvati. The current Annapurna Mandir was constructed in the 18th century by Peshwa Baji Rao 1

In Hindu history, there are two popular beliefs behind the origin of this temple.

According to one belief, once the goddess Parvati closed all three eyes of her husband Shiva. Due to this, the entire world was filled with darkness. Parvati s

Annapurna Devi Mandir is one of the most famous Hindu temples in the holy city of Varanasi. This temple has great religious importance in Hinduism and is dedicated to the goddess Annapurna. Annapurna is the Hindu goddess for nourishment and is a form of the goddess Parvati. The current Annapurna Mandir was constructed in the 18th century by Peshwa Baji Rao 1

In Hindu history, there are two popular beliefs behind the origin of this temple.

According to one belief, once the goddess Parvati closed all three eyes of her husband Shiva. Due to this, the entire world was filled with darkness. Parvati stole her fair complexion (Gauri form). She asked Shiva for his help to reacquire her Gauri form. Shiva asked her to donate anna (food) in Varanasi. Hence, she took the form of Annapurna (the goddess of food) with a golden pot and ladle and donated food in Varanasi.

According to another belief, once Shiva commented that the entire world (including food) is maya (illusion). Parvati, the goddess of food, got angry and decided to demonstrate the importance of food by making all the food on earth disappear. The world started to suffer due to hunger. Shiva finally came to Parvati and acknowledged the importance of food, begging for food at her door. Parvati became happy, offered food by her own hands to Shiva and then made a kitchen in Varanasi for her devotees.

The Annapoorneshwari Temple is a Hindu temple dedicated to the goddess Annapoorneshwari, located at Horanadu, Karnataka, India, 100 km from Chikmagalur in the thick forests and valleys of the Western Ghats of Karnataka. It is situated on the banks of river Bhadra.
